quotes: On 26 July 2007, Sirleaf celebrated Liberia's 160th Independence Day under the theme 'Liberia at 160: Reclaiming the future.'
On 4 October 2010, Sirleaf signed into law a Freedom of Information bill, the first legislation of its kind in West Africa.
On 1 April 2011, Sirleaf told reporters that she planned to charge an opposition candidate with sedition for organizing a rally protesting corruption in the government.
The United States became the first country to grant debt relief to Liberia, waiving the full $391 million owed to it by Liberia in early 2007.
In September of that year, the G-8 headed by German Chancellor Angela Merkel provided $324.5 million to paying off 60% of Liberia's debt to the International Monetary Fund.
In April 2009, the government successfully wrote off an additional $1.2 billion in foreign commercial debt in a deal that saw the government buy back the debt at a 97% discounted rate.
The country was deemed eligible to participate in the Heavily Indebted Poor Countries initiative in 2008.
In June 2010, the country reached the completion point of the
national debt, which stood at approximately US$4.9 billion in 2006, a top priority for her administration.

organizations.name: The African Editor's Union
quotes: she became the first sitting head of state to receive the Friend of the Media in Africa Award from The African Editor's Union.

organizations.name: International Development Association
quotes: In April 2009, the government successfully wrote off an additional $1.2 billion in foreign commercial debt in a deal that saw the government buy back the debt at a 97% discounted rate through financing provided by the International Development Association, Germany, Norway, the United States, and the United Kingdom.

roles.title: President
quotes: President Sirleaf issued an Executive Order making education free and compulsory for all elementary school aged children.

roles.title: National Orator
quotes: She took an unprecedented and symbolic move by asking 25-year-old Liberian activist Kimmie Weeks to serve as National Orator for the celebrations.

to live at her personal home in Monrovia.
Sirleaf celebrated Liberia's 160th Independence Day under the theme 'Liberia at 160: Reclaiming the future.'
On 4 October 2010, Sirleaf signed into law a Freedom of Information bill, the first legislation of its kind in West Africa.
In September of that year, the G-8 headed by German Chancellor Angela Merkel provided $324.5 million to paying off 60% of Liberia's debt to the International Monetary Fund.

In April 2009, the government successfully wrote off an additional $1.2 billion in foreign commercial debt in a deal that saw the government buy back the debt at a 97% discounted rate through financing provided by the International Development Association, Germany, Norway, the United States, and the United Kingdom.
The United States became the first country to grant debt relief to Liberia, waiving the full $391 million owed to it by Liberia in early 2007.

In April 2009, the government successfully wrote off an additional $1.2 billion in foreign commercial debt in a deal that saw the government buy back the debt at a 97% discounted rate through financing provided by the International Development Association, Germany, Norway, the United States, and the United Kingdom.
